paper_metadata.title: Assessing Potassium Mass Balances in Different Countries and Scales
paper_metadata.journal: Improving Potassium Recommendations for Agricultural Crops (Chapter 11)
paper_metadata.study_region: Global (Australia, Southeast Asia, China, India, Sub-Saharan Africa, North Africa, United States, Brazil, Southern Cone of Latin America)
paper_metadata.primary_focus: Potassium (K) mass balances, nutrient use efficiency, soil K fertility, crop yields

research_methodology.experimental_design: The chapter synthesizes existing research and data on K mass balances from various studies conducted at different scales (farm-gate, field, farm-system, regional, national) and across multiple countries. It discusses the methodologies used in these underlying studies, including data sources and calculation approaches for nutrient balance metrics.

temporal_scope.data_collection_frequency: Varies by reviewed study (e.g., annual, multi-year averages, decadal trends)
temporal_scope.seasonal_coverage: Not explicitly detailed for all reviewed studies, but seasonal conditions are mentioned as a factor influencing grain and red meat production variability in Australia.
monitoring_timeline: Australia: 2004-2007 (KCl imports peak), 2009 (K fertilizer use low), 2012 (K2SO4 imports peak), 2016-2017 (K fertilizer use), 2007-2008 and 2011-2012 (regional PNBI K), 2010-2014 (Southern Australian grain farms survey)
Southeast Asia: 2010-2011 (crop year for K balance estimation)

China: 1978-2015 (fertilizer consumption, grain production), 1961-1997 (provincial K depletion), 2005-2007 (winter wheat study), 1990-2012 (soil test K and crop responses), 1980-2010 (farmland PNBI K), 1980-1989, 1990-1999, 2000-2009, 2010-2015 (comprehensive K balance)
India: 2014 (K2O consumption), 2015-2016 (crop production statistics), 1970-2005 (fertilizer response ratio), 1999-2000 (annual negative PNBI), 2007 and 2011 (PNBI K across states)

North Africa: 1980s (earlier research), 'last few decades' (K deficiency symptoms), 'last decades' (research limited), '30 years ago' (most recent research programs), 10-17 years (Morocco cumulative studies)
Brazil: 2015 (K fertilizer consumption), 2009-2012 (recent survey average), 1988-2012 (trends in mass balances)
Southern Cone of Latin America: 'last years' (K2O consumption), 2012-2014 (Argentina PNB K), 1996-2015 (Paraguay PNB K), 1990, 2000, 2010 (Uruguay PNBI K)

spatial_scope.geographic_coverage: Global, with detailed case studies from Australia, Southeast Asia (Indonesia, Malaysia, Philippines, Thailand, Vietnam), China (30 provinces, 6 agricultural regions), India (states, regions), Sub-Saharan Africa (continental, countries, regions within Kenya), North Africa (Morocco, Algeria, Tunisia), United States (contiguous 48 states, 4 regional groups), Brazil (regions, states), and Southern Cone of Latin America (Argentina, Bolivia, Chile, Paraguay, Uruguay).
site_characteristics: Australia: Sugarcane-growing areas, lower rainfall grain-growing regions, high rainfall zones, sand and loam soil types, Vertosols.
Southeast Asia: Major production areas for rice, maize, sugarcane, oil palm.
China: Northeast (NE), Northcentral (NC), Northwest (NW), Southeast (SE), Southwest (SW) regions; rice-based systems, wheat-maize rotations, potato production fields, vegetable production fields.

India: Alluvial (Inceptisols and Entisols), Red and Lateritic (Alfisols and Ultisols), Black (Vertisols) soils; Indo-Gangetic Plains (IGP); rice-wheat, rice-rice, maize-wheat, pigeon pea-wheat, sugarcane-ratoon-wheat, sesbania-rice-wheat, pearl millet-mustard, pearl millet-wheat, maize-Bengal gram, rice-green gram, cotton-pearl millet cropping systems.
Sub-Saharan Africa: Sub-humid savannahs, highlands, humid forests, wetlands, arid zones; smallholder farms, plots at different distances from homesteads.
North Africa: Mediterranean climate zones, arid and semi-arid climate zones; calcimagnesic, fersialitic, clay-rich vertisols; rainfed and irrigated areas, greenhouse crop production systems.
United States: Arid western half, northeastern states, corn and soybean-growing states, cotton-growing areas.
Brazil: Midwest region (soybean and maize production), various states.

Southern Cone of Latin America: Pampas and Gran Chaco regions (Argentina, Uruguay), southern highlands (eastern Paraguay), eastern lowlands (Bolivia), central valleys and southern volcanic regions (Chile); Mollisols, Alfisols, Ultisols, Oxisols, Vertisols, Alluvial soils, Andisols, Entisols, Inceptisols.
spatial_scope.coordinates: Not explicitly provided in the text for the study regions, but specific locations are named (e.g., Sidi Kacem, Mohammedia, Tessaout, Souihla, Afourer, Boulaouane, Dar Bouazza in Morocco; Gazipur in Bangladesh).
spatial_scope.regional_representativeness: The chapter aims to provide a global overview of K mass balances, covering major agricultural production areas and diverse agro-ecological zones.

sample_design.replication_levels: Not explicitly stated for the review, but implied for the underlying experimental studies (e.g., 'long-term experiments', 'multi-location studies').
sample_design.randomization_approach: Not explicitly stated for the review.
controls_and_treatments: Farmers’ fertilization practice (FFP), State recommendation (SR), State recommendation with additional micro- and secondary nutrients (SR+M) (India)
sample_design.statistical_power: Not explicitly quantified, but 'small sample sizes' are noted as a limitation for some Australian data.

measurement_protocols: Estimating nutrient mass balances using information on nutrient additions and removals.
Calculation of Partial Nutrient Balance (PNB), Partial Factor Productivity (PFP), Partial Nutrient Balance Intensity (PNBI), Agronomic Efficiency (AE), Recovery Efficiency (RE).
Soil test K values (exchangeable K, non-exchangeable K).
Crop K concentration in harvested biomass (e.g., wheat grain, maize grain, cane sugar, oil palm fresh fruit bunch).
Estimation of K contribution from organic sources (manure, crop residues, mill wastes, cake manure).
Estimation of K loss from soils (runoff, erosion, leaching).
quality_control: Emphasis on reliable data for crop production, fertilizer use, and crop product nutrient density.
Consideration of all nutrient sources and regional relevance for data transparency and auditability.

analytical_precision.K_concentration_wheat_grain_variability: ±14% of the mean value (4606 mg K kg–1)

analysis_methods: Ratio calculations (PNB = outputs/inputs, PFP = yield/inputs, AE = increase in yield/inputs, RE = increase in uptake/inputs).
Linear regression (for temporal trends in USA PNB K).
Geostatistical approach (mentioned for a study in West Bengal, India).
statistical_approach.significance_testing: Qualitative statements of 'significant negative K balances', 'significant trend emerged'.
statistical_approach.uncertainty_quantification: Acknowledged 'considerable uncertainty' in nutrient balances, particularly at regional and national scales, due to various data limitations and assumptions.
statistical_approach.model_validation: NuGIS model used for USA K budgets. Nutrient balance models are discussed as tools for assessment.

primary_measurements.units: kg K ha–1 or kg K2O ha–1
primary_measurements.measurement_context: Calculated as sum of K inputs – sum of K outputs
Audited period, denominator as area of agricultural production

primary_measurements.parameter: K application rate (Southern Australian Grain Farms, where K was used)
primary_measurements.measurement_context: On canola and cereals, respectively (2010-2014 survey)

primary_measurements.parameter: Median PNB K (Southern Australian Grain Farms, where K was used)
Median PFP K (Southern Australian Grain Farms, where K was used)
Average negative K balance (China, potato on-farm trials)

primary_measurements.measurement_context: Higher for cash crops than grain crops
Average deficit in 1980 to surplus in 2010
Average annual output, 99% from crop removal

primary_measurements.parameter: K removal by cereals vs. applied K (India)
primary_measurements.measurement_context: Removal is 11 times more than applied K

primary_measurements.parameter: K uptake from soil reserves (India, rice-wheat, K omission plots)
primary_measurements.measurement_context: Average across multi-location studies (Tiwari et al. 2006)

primary_measurements.parameter: Net negative K balance (India, Tewatia et al. 2017)

primary_measurements.measurement_context: From 1985 to 2000 in a clay-loam soil

primary_measurements.parameter: Exchangeable K decrease (India, no K fertilizer)
primary_measurements.measurement_context: Average across 60 on-farm locations during one rice-wheat cycle

primary_measurements.parameter: Non-exchangeable K decrease (India, no K fertilizer)
primary_measurements.measurement_context: Average across 60 on-farm locations during one rice-wheat cycle

primary_measurements.parameter: K losses due to erosion (Sub-Saharan Africa)
Largest K losses (PNBI K, Sub-Saharan Africa)
primary_measurements.measurement_context: In sub-humid savannahs of West Africa and highlands/sub-humid areas of East/Southern Africa

primary_measurements.parameter: Moderate K losses (PNBI K, Sub-Saharan Africa)
primary_measurements.measurement_context: In humid forests and wetlands of south-central Africa and Sudan

primary_measurements.parameter: Lowest K losses (PNBI K, Sub-Saharan Africa)
primary_measurements.measurement_context: In arid zones in southern and West Africa
Average percentage of total consumed N, P, and K

primary_measurements.parameter: Wheat yield threshold for K response (Morocco)
primary_measurements.measurement_context: Wheat responded to added K fertilizer only when yield was higher than this value

primary_measurements.parameter: K fertilizer use in greenhouse crops (NW Morocco)

primary_measurements.measurement_context: Percentage of total consumed N, P, and K fertilizer

primary_measurements.parameter: PNB K (USA, Group C - arid western states)

primary_measurements.measurement_context: Proportion of total K fertilizer consumption

primary_measurements.parameter: K fertilizer consumption (Southern Cone of Latin America)
Soil test K concentrations (Argentina, central Pampas)
Reduction in soil test K (Argentina, central Pampas)
primary_measurements.measurement_context: From pristine (990–1140 mg K kg–1) to agricultural soils
Annual average in main harvestable products
Percentage of soil samples above critical levels (> 0.5 cmol(+) kg–1 or 195 mg K kg–1)

statistical_relationships.effect_size: PNBs are likely to reflect the stage of economic development and agricultural industrialization as well as production systems management (Economic Kuznets curve concept).

statistical_relationships.significance_level: R2 values provided (0.825, 0.623, 0.566, 0.737 respectively), indicating significant trends for most US regions except Group C.
statistical_relationships.effect_size: Annual change rates of 1.3% (USA), 1.1% (Area A, B), 1.8% (Area D).

temporal_patterns.trend_description: Increased with time between 1990 and 2012. Slightly for grain crops, dramatically for cash crops.
Changed from average deficit to surplus.
Increased in all regions over time, greatest for SE, least for NW and NE.
Increased over time in all regions.
Increased from lowest value in 1984 to a relatively stable positive value in 2015. NE region stayed in deficit.
Significant decreases in areas of north-western India.
Increasing trend (becoming increasingly negative in terms of balance, as PNB K > 1 means removal > input).
Decreasing trend (similar to N), with a temporary increase in 2009 due to higher fertilizer prices.
Decreased from 3-4 (1996-2003) to 2-3 (since 2003), indicating an improvement but still high deficit.

groups_compared: Lower rainfall grain-growing regions of Western Australia, South Australia, and Central Queensland

comparative_results.comparison_type: PNB K and PNBI K by industry (Australia)
comparative_results.practical_significance: All industries except cotton have more K removed than applied as fertilizer. Largest apparent deficits in grains, sugar, and dairy industries.

comparative_results.comparison_type: PNBI K across Southeast Asian countries (2010-2011)
comparative_results.practical_significance: Rice: deficits in Indonesia, Philippines, Thailand; surpluses in Malaysia, Vietnam. Maize: deficit only in Philippines. Oil palm: surpluses in Indonesia, Malaysia, Thailand; deficit in Philippines. Sugarcane: surpluses in Indonesia, Malaysia, Vietnam; deficits in Philippines, Thailand.

comparative_results.comparison_type: K fertilizer requirement by crop (Southeast Asia)
comparative_results.practical_significance: Order of K fertilizer needed: oil palm > rice > sugarcane > maize.

comparative_results.comparison_type: PNB K between cash and grain crops (China)
comparative_results.practical_significance: PNB K was higher for cash crops (mean 2.1) than for grain crops (mean 1.3), indicating higher K depletion in cash crops.
Western region had the highest negative K balance (3.8 Mt), followed by northern (2.6 Mt), eastern (1.9 Mt), and southern (1.3 Mt).
Highest for sugarcane (–121), fruits (–71), plantation crops (–58). Lowest for pulses (–15). Food grains (–40) have profound effect due to large area.

comparative_results.comparison_type: K losses across agro-ecological zones (Sub-Saharan Africa)
comparative_results.practical_significance: Largest losses (20–50) in high potential areas, moderate (10–20) in humid areas, lowest (5–15) in arid zones.

comparative_results.comparison_type: PNBI K across regions in Kenya
comparative_results.practical_significance: Rift Valley had the lowest balance (–34), North Eastern the highest (–5).

comparative_results.comparison_type: K balance in Morocco with/without K application
comparative_results.practical_significance: All systems showed negative PNBI K without K application. With K, some became positive (Mohammedia, Dar-Bouazza) while others remained negative (Sidi Kacem, Tessaout, Souihla, Afourer, Boulaouane).
Most balanced in soybean (0.99), rice (0.86), sugarcane (0.85). Lowest in coffee (0.20) and wheat (0.33). Common bean had PNB K > 1 (1.20).

geographic_details.coordinates: Not explicitly provided in the text for the study regions, but specific locations are named.
geographic_details.landscape_position: Soilscape (underlying geology and position on the landscape), within-farm soil fertility gradients (distance from homestead).

climate_characteristics.climate_classification: Mediterranean climate (North Africa), arid and semi-arid climate zones (North Africa), sub-humid savannahs (Sub-Saharan Africa), humid forests (Sub-Saharan Africa), wetlands (Sub-Saharan Africa), arid zones (Sub-Saharan Africa).

temperature_patterns.North_Africa: Colder winter and dry and hot during the summer (Mediterranean climate).

precipitation_patterns.North_Africa: Rainfall during the colder winter, dry and hot during the summer, lack of sufficient rainfall.

soil_properties.soil_classification: Alluvial (Inceptisols and Entisols), Red and Lateritic (Alfisols and Ultisols), Black (Vertisols) soils (India); calcimagnesic, fersialitic, and clay-rich vertisols (North Africa); Mollisols, Alfisols, Ultisols, Oxisols, Vertisols, Alluvial soils, Andisols, Entisols, Inceptisols (Southern Cone of Latin America).
soil_properties.texture: Clay-loam soil (Bangladesh), light-textured soil (Bangladesh), fine-textured soils (Tunisia), coarse-textured soils (Tunisia), sandy soils (Algeria).
soil_properties.organic_matter: Generally low in organic matter (North Africa).

chemical_properties.K_content: High available and reserve soil K (India, Alluvial soils); low K availability due to higher Ca and Mg (India, Black soils); lower K content (India, Red and Lateritic soils); low exchangeable K and high spatial variability (North Africa); high native fertility (Southern Cone, Mollisols); high concentration of nutrient cations (Southern Cone, Alfisols); low plant-available K (Brazil, Midwest); low exchangeable K concentrations (Sub-Saharan Africa); low non-exchangeable K (India, West Bengal).

physical_properties.Southern_Cone: Vertisols have challenging soil physical properties.

land_use_context.current_land_use: Grazing land (87% of agricultural land in Australia), crop production, improved pastures, viticulture, horticulture, beef, sheep, dairy industries, arable land, permanent cropland.
land_use_context.management_intensity: Intensified agricultural production, intensive cropping, high-yield levels, intensification through improved crop and nutrient management, expansion of irrigated area.
land_use_context.historical_context: Long-term intensive cropping, continuous cultivation for many decades, long history of crop production without proper soil management, replacement of pastures by annual crops (soybean).
sustainability_metrics: Soil health metrics (not directly quantified by PNB/PNBI, but discussed as incomplete aspects)
Environmental impacts (nutrient loss to other sinks, runoff, erosion, leaching)

yield_levels.Thailand_sugarcane_yield_threshold: 30 t ha–1 (dry cane) for negative K balances

types: Organic fertilizer (manure, crop residues, mill wastes, cake manure)
timing: Single fertilizer application (carryover to second crop)

irrigation.system_type: Not specified (e.g., irrigated long-term experiments, improved irrigation facilities)

water_amounts.India_irrigation_water_K_contribution: 125 kg K ha–1 (for near-neutral K balance in rice-wheat)

input_rates.Southeast_Asia_K_applied_2010_2011: Total 479 kt K2O (Rice), 152 kt K2O (Maize), 190 kt K2O (Sugarcane), 1813 kt K2O (Oil palm)

output_measurements.Southeast_Asia_K_removed_2010_2011: Total 507 kt K2O (Rice), 66 kt K2O (Maize), 175 kt K2O (Sugarcane), 981 kt K2O (Oil palm)
output_measurements.China_average_K_output_1980_2015: 14.78 Mt K2O (146 kg K2O ha–1 year–1)

study_timeline.start_date: 1961 (earliest data point for China K depletion)
study_timeline.end_date: 2017 (latest data point for Australia K use)
study_timeline.monitoring_frequency: Varies by underlying study, but often annual or multi-year averages for national/regional balances.

seasonal_variations.seasonal_pattern: Highly variable due to seasonal conditions.

long_term_trends.sustainability_implications: Shifted K balance from negative to positive, improving sustainability.
Increased soil K in cash crops, but grain crops still below critical levels in some regions.
Indicates improved K management and sustainability due to increased K fertilizer use and residue retention.
Identified as a major concern, linked to imbalanced fertilization and low K use.
On-farm studies showed declines in exchangeable and non-exchangeable K fractions in intensively cultivated areas, impacting future sustainability.

long_term_trends.trend_direction: Increasing (meaning K removal is increasingly exceeding K input)
long_term_trends.sustainability_implications: Leading to negative K balances that are becoming increasingly negative, indicating depletion.
Indicates a shift towards more intensive cropping systems with higher inputs, leading to lower PNB values.

long_term_trends.parameter: Soil K availability (Southern Cone of Latin America)
long_term_trends.sustainability_implications: Negative K mass balances have reduced soil K availability, leading to K deficiencies and crop responses to K fertilization in some areas.

inter_annual_variability.Australia_grain_red_meat_production: Highly variable due to seasonal conditions.
inter_annual_variability.China_nutrient_balances: Can vary considerably from year to year.

spatial_variability.Australia_PNBI_K: Patterns largely reflect the balance of enterprises and inherent soil K fertility.
spatial_variability.China_K_balance: Significant spatial differences at provincial and regional scales.
spatial_variability.India_PNBI_K: Large negative values in northern, western, and eastern regions.
spatial_variability.Sub_Saharan_Africa_PNBI_K: Varies greatly among different cropping systems and agro-ecological zones.
spatial_variability.North_Africa_soil_K: High spatial variability of K in soils, differences among soil categories.
spatial_variability.Brazil_PNB_K_states: Wide range of results (0.54 to 3.17) across states.

measurement_uncertainty.Nutrient_balances_general: Considerable uncertainty, particularly at regional and national scales.
measurement_uncertainty.Crop_K_concentration: ±14% error embedded in data for wheat grain K concentration.

drivers_of_variability: Resource management at farm level (wealth categories, distance from homestead)
Access, price, and affordability of fertilizers
Information on nutrient removal by some crops
Nutrient loss by runoff and erosion
Nutrient concentration of manures and organic supplements

methodological_strengths: Comprehensive overview of K mass balances across different countries and scales.
Integration of data from various sources (FAOSTAT, IFA, national statistics, farm surveys, peer-reviewed literature).
Use of established metrics (PNB, PNBI, PFP, AE, RE) for consistency.
Highlights the importance of temporal trends for sustainability assessment.
Acknowledges the contextual nature of nutrient balances.
Identifies opportunities for improving K application and management.
methodological_limitations: Nutrient balances involve considerable uncertainty, especially at regional and national scales.
Regional variations in crop K concentration introduce error (e.g., ±14% for wheat grain).
Inadequate information on nutrient removal by some crops.
Lack of information on the contribution of manure and other organic sources.
Inability to fully account for nutrient loss by runoff and erosion.
Poor fertilizer use data and imprecise survey questions leading to under-reporting.
Difficulty in disaggregating fertilizer use data by production region and crop.
Residual nutrient carryover and K released from soil minerals are often not accounted for.
PNB does not describe internal K transformation pathways (e.g., dissolution, fixation).
PNB is not a direct quantitative estimate of K loss from the system.
NUE indicators do not directly reference soil health or soil nutrient concentrations, making them incomplete for sustainability description.
Highest values of some indicators may occur at lowest application levels, potentially giving unrealistic impressions.
Survey sample sizes can be small, leading to up-scaling errors.
Averages provide limited intelligence for farm-level balances.
Non-exchangeable K is often not measured in routine soil tests, leading to unnoticed declines.
data_quality_assessment.data_completeness: The chapter provides a comprehensive synthesis based on available data, but acknowledges data gaps and limitations in the underlying sources.

measurement_precision.K_concentration_variability: Wheat grain K concentration varied by ±14% of the mean value.

representativeness.spatial_representativeness: Varies by region and study scale; some data are aggregated at national/regional levels, while others are from specific farm/field surveys. Representativeness is a noted challenge.
representativeness.temporal_representativeness: Data spans different time periods for different regions, with some long-term trends analyzed, but 'snapshots' are also common.
representativeness.system_representativeness: Comparisons are valid only among similar systems due to high variability.

uncertainty_sources: Regional variations in crop K concentration.
Inadequate information on nutrient removal by some crops.
Lack of information on the contribution of manure.
Inability to account for nutrient loss by runoff and erosion.
Amount of grain retained on-farm for seed, animal feed, or domestic use.
Definition of crop production area (country, agriculture, arable farming, sown, fertilized, harvested).
Variability in nutrient concentration of manures and organic supplements.
Confounding effects of fertilizer practices on other crops in rotation.
Not accounting for K released from soil minerals.
Small survey sample sizes leading to up-scaling errors.
Regional differences in product nutrient density, rotations, and recycled matter use.
validation_evidence: NuGIS model used for USA K budgets.
Soil test data re-analysis (Christy et al. 2015) to assess K response likelihood.
Comparison of K use with fertilizer industry-reported consumption (Australia).
On-farm studies showing declines in soil K fractions in response to negative balances.

comparative_studies: The entire chapter serves as a comparative study, presenting K mass balance assessments from different countries and scales.
Benchmarking data is provided through the comparison of PNB/PNBI values across regions, crops, and management systems.
literature_integration.theoretical_framework: The core theoretical framework is the principle of mass balance applied to crop nutrients. The concept of the Economic Kuznets curve is also introduced to explain trends in resource use metrics.
data_sources: FAOSTAT (Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations)
USDA FAS (United States Department of Agriculture Foreign Agriculture Service)
DAC (Agriculture Census Division, Department of Agriculture and Cooperation, Ministry of Agriculture, Government of India)
ANDA (Associação Nacional para Difusão de Adubos, Brazil)
IBGE (Instituto Brasileiro de Geografia e Estatística, Brazil)
AICRP-IFS (All India Coordinated Research Project on Integrated Farming Systems)
benchmarking_data: Typical ranges for K use efficiency metrics (PFPK, PNBK, AEK, REK) for cereal crops.
PNB K and PNBI K values for various Australian industries.
PNBI K values for different crops and countries in Southeast Asia.
PNB K and PNBI K values for different regions and cropping systems in China and India.
PNBI K ranges for countries and regions in Sub-Saharan Africa and North Africa.
PNB K trends and values for different regions in the USA and Brazil.
PNB K and PNBI K values for countries and crops in the Southern Cone of Latin America.
validation_studies: Soil test data re-analysis (Christy et al. 2015) to assess K response likelihood in Australia.
On-farm studies in India showing declines in exchangeable and non-exchangeable K fractions in the absence of added K fertilizer, supporting negative PNBI K findings.
Crop yield responses to K fertilization in areas with negative K balances (e.g., Argentina, Uruguay, India, North Africa).

extraction_metadata.data_richness_assessment: High. The paper is a comprehensive review, providing a wealth of quantitative data, regional contexts, and methodological insights from numerous underlying studies.
potential_ambiguities: The term 'study' in the context of this review chapter refers to the synthesis of existing data, not a single new experiment. Details on specific experimental designs (e.g., replication, randomization) are often implicit from the cited literature rather than explicitly stated for the review itself.
Units for K balance metrics (PNBI K) can be kg K ha–1 or kg K2O ha–1, and the paper uses both, requiring careful distinction.
Interpretation of PNB K values: PNB K > 1 indicates K removal exceeds K input, implying depletion, which can be counter-intuitive if one expects >1 to be a 'surplus'. The paper clarifies this.
Some data points are averages over multiple years or regions, and the variability within those averages is not always fully detailed.

The exact methodologies for calculating K balances (e.g., which inputs/outputs were included) vary across the reviewed studies, as summarized in Table 11.18, which adds complexity to direct comparisons.
extraction_limitations: As a review chapter, the paper does not contain raw data or detailed experimental protocols for the individual studies it synthesizes. Therefore, specific details like precise coordinates for all sites, full statistical analyses (e.g., p-values for all comparisons), or complete lists of all measured parameters are not available.
The paper focuses on K; detailed information on other nutrients (N, P) is only provided when directly relevant to K balances or overall NPK trends.
recommended_validation_checks: Cross-reference specific quantitative values with the original cited papers for more detailed context and uncertainty measures.
Verify the definitions and calculation methods of PNB and PNBI for each regional assessment, as they can vary slightly (e.g., inclusion of organic inputs, specific loss pathways).
